Clearly we should have some test cases that run Eclipse or subsets of Eclipse in strict mode.  Perhaps we should also run some builds in strict mode...

Is there any way we can include warnings in the compile logs of the automated builds.

As to this particular problem.  It involves using the FileManager from org.eclipse.osgi which is in a non-public package.  I'm in the middle of breaking this out into a new package which can be used by others.  I hope to get this in today and modify all the equinox bundles over to use this new package.

Created an attachment (id=32941)
Patch to use new StorageManager

This is a patch to use the newly proposed StorageManager API.  The org.eclipse.osgi.storeagemanager package is not marked as x-friends or x-internal and should be available for other bundles to use.

Pascal, can you review and release.  I also would like some eyes on the javadoc of the org.eclipse.osgi.storagemanager.

Notice that the patch includes changes to the registry bundle manifest to use Import-Package instead of requiring the system bundle.  The bundle manifest change is not really needed to fix this bug.

Overall
The API for the class seems to be a bit to precise as to what is going on behind the scene. I would remove that or phrase it such that it is clear to people that this is nothing more than an explanation on how this is implemented. If we leave it this way I'm afraid that it would block us from further change.

The concept of "target" is confusing. What can't we talk about file or managed file.

The API should also contain a simple snippet demonstrating how to it.

Details:
The sentence "If another entity updates the directory, the storage manager is able to detect the change." should be more precise as from that I can understand that the file manager will provide a listener mechanism for me to listen to what is going on.

I'm wondering if we should not make the class final.

We should make a note of where the initial implementation is coming from so we 
can easily go back to the history of the file later on.

The method InputStream getInputStream(String) doc says: "This call is equivalent to calling <code>getInputStream(target, OPEN_BEST_AVAILABLE)." but in fact this method is no longer API.
I forgot that there is also here a usage of system properties

I updated the java doc to remove the usage of target.  Instead managed file is used.  I tried to remove some of the implementation details out of the class javadoc and replaced it with a general description of the principals the class.  Still need to add some code snippets to demonstrate the API.

What about releasing the patch to registry?

I released the registry code and updated the javadoc of StorageManager with an example. I'm still not super happy with the phrasing of the API. Should not we remove the second paragraph or make sure that this is just an implementation detail to help the user understand the behavior.

Thanks for the code example.  I moved the implementation details to the bottom of the javadoc and made it clear that the details are only provided to help with understanding the behavior of the class.  If it is still unclear then I vote to remove the paragraph.

Marking as fixed for M5.
